Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Process and Consequences of the Work of 911 Dispatchers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research seeks to understand the process and consequences of 911 dispatchers' daily work. The study focuses on how dispatchers understand and respond to citizens' emergency situations communicated through 911 lines, how dispatchers code citizens' calls in the Computer Aided Dispatch (CAD) system, the source of dispatcher stress, and how dispatchers cope with stress, are trained, treated and perceived by their colleagues and related organizations. Extensive fieldwork will be conducted in an urban police department's emergency communication center where 911 calls are answered and units dispatched. An analysis will be completed of data from day-to-day actions in the center, interviews with dispatchers, directors, supervisors and trainees, records of past calls, incoming calls, information from CAD system, casual interactions in the operation room and dining area, training manuals and books, as well as other relevant documents and files from the media, the city, state court, and the state police. This study contributes to three bodies of literature in the field of sociology: state classification practices, street-level bureaucracy and the sociology of the professions. The empirical analysis seeks to answer the classical and present-day theoretical question of how the state is represented to and experienced by citizens.

The research examines the process through which the state classification system is applied and the costs and consequences of this process. The field site provides access to all incoming phone-calls, phone records, training materials, on-site observation interviews as well as CAD log-ins from an urban, big-city police department. The study will potentially demonstrate how street-level state employees (911 dispatchers) engage in state classification that bridges complex social life and clear-cut bureaucratic categories. It contributes to an increased understanding of how state categories are applied and reproduced, and how the correspondence between the outside world and state forms of representation is accomplished through the constant efforts of human agents. The research will also provide practical and policy-relevant guidance regarding the stress and trails experienced by 911 dispatchers and provide for citizens a greater understanding of how the 911 dispatch system works.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC

AWARD NO. 1539822

The findings of the awarded project show that 911 dispatchers play a key role as the very first link between the callers faced with emergencies and the official actions initiated for response. Dispatchers serve as human filters that translate complex reported incidents into codes in the Computer Aided Dispatch system, which dictate the public safety actions taken to assist the citizens. Fire, police and medical matters are handled with varied levels of human discretion and technological automation. Determining the victims’ situation through conversations over the phone and selecting one corresponding code in hundreds of possible categories is the crucial step in the process of responding to 911 calls. It requires emotional investment and detachment simultaneously on the part of the 911 dispatchers, and this conflicted demand causes high level of stress and turnover on the job. Such stress needs to be coped with and channeled through sufficient institutional recognition and resources, timely peer support, mutual understanding between police, fire, medical and 911 personnel and heightened public awareness of the nature of the daily work of 911 dispatchers. The effectiveness of the 911 emergency response system also relies on the dispatchers’ visualization of on-going incidents, their memory of past incidents, and their assessment of the environment that the victims and front-line responders find themselves in, all of which causes psychological trauma experienced by 911 dispatchers. Because of dispatchers’ lower status and lack of visibility compared to other public safety professions, the way they manage said stress and trauma tends to be negative, individualized and unsustainable, which persists it in the long run and compromises dispatchers’ overall well-being and job satisfaction.

The findings of the awarded project have been presented at the annual conference held by the National Emergency Number Association in the summer of 2015 and the virtual conference held by 911 Wellness Foundation in the fall.
